title: Hands-on Exercise 00: Working with tidyverse
text:
Loading tidyverse onto r environment by using the code chunk below

pacman:: p_load(tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 00: Working with tidyverse
text:
Loading tidyverse onto r environment by using the code chunk below

pacman:: p_load(tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 00: Working with tidyverse
text:
Importing Data
Code chunk below uses read_csv() of readr to import REALIS2019.csv into r environment as a tibble data.frame.

realis2019 <- read_csv("data/REALIS2019.csv")
popdata_fat <- read_csv("data/PopData2019_fat.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 00: Working with tidyverse
text:
Pivoting Data

#pivot_longer() "lengthens" data, increasing the number of rows and decreasing the number of columns

popdata_long <- popdata_fat %>% #pipe: to combine diff functions tgt
  pivot_longer(c(3:21), #column
               names_to = "Age Group", #column headers to rows
               values_to = "Population") #values to rows


write_rds(popdata_long, "rds/popdata_long.rds") #rds: compact r file

title: Hands-on Exercise 00: Working with tidyverse
text:
Selecting Data

realis2019_selected <- realis2019 %>%
  select(`Project Name`,
         `Transacted Price ($)`,
         `Type of Sale`,
         `Unit Price ($ psm)`,
         `Property Type`)
realis2019_selected

# A tibble: 19,515 × 5
   `Project Name`     `Transacted Price ($)` `Type of Sale` `Unit Price ($ psm)`
   <chr>                               <dbl> <chr>                         <dbl>
 1 PEIRCE VIEW                        840000 Resale                         7434
 2 FLORIDA PARK                      3040000 Resale                         9737
 3 BULLION PARK                       860000 Resale                        11467
 4 CASTLE GREEN                      1000000 Resale                         9346
 5 HAPPY ESTATE                      7000000 Resale                        10183
 6 TEACHER'S HOUSING…                2880000 Resale                        12659
 7 THE PANORAMA                      1510000 Resale                        16064
 8 THE PANORAMA                       710000 Resale                        16905
 9 CHIP THYE GARDEN                  2800000 Resale                        13500
10 TEACHER'S HOUSING…                2300000 Resale                         9935
# ℹ 19,505 more rows
# ℹ 1 more variable: `Property Type` <chr>

title: Hands-on Exercise 00: Working with tidyverse
text:
Filtering Data using dplyr package

realis2019_filtered <- realis2019_selected %>%
  filter (`Property Type` == "Condominium" |
            `Property Type` == "Apartment") %>%
  filter (`Type of Sale` == "New Sale") %>%
  filter (`Unit Price ($ psm)` <= 13000)

realis2019_filtered

# A tibble: 87 × 5
   `Project Name`     `Transacted Price ($)` `Type of Sale` `Unit Price ($ psm)`
   <chr>                               <dbl> <chr>                         <dbl>
 1 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1029000 New Sale                      12863
 2 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                 871000 New Sale                      12809
 3 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1940000 New Sale                      12848
 4 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1030000 New Sale                      12875
 5 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                2061000 New Sale                      12962
 6 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                 762000 New Sale                      12915
 7 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1001000 New Sale                      12513
 8 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1271000 New Sale                      12838
 9 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1310000 New Sale                      12970
10 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1339000 New Sale                      13000
# ℹ 77 more rows
# ℹ 1 more variable: `Property Type` <chr>



Putting all together

realis2019_end <- realis2019 %>%
  select(`Project Name`,
         `Transacted Price ($)`,
         `Type of Sale`,
         `Unit Price ($ psm)`,
         `Property Type`)   %>%
  filter (`Property Type` == "Condominium" |
            `Property Type` == "Apartment") %>%
  filter (`Type of Sale` == "New Sale") %>%
  filter (`Unit Price ($ psm)` <= 13000)

realis2019_end

# A tibble: 87 × 5
   `Project Name`     `Transacted Price ($)` `Type of Sale` `Unit Price ($ psm)`
   <chr>                               <dbl> <chr>                         <dbl>
 1 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1029000 New Sale                      12863
 2 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                 871000 New Sale                      12809
 3 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1940000 New Sale                      12848
 4 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1030000 New Sale                      12875
 5 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                2061000 New Sale                      12962
 6 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                 762000 New Sale                      12915
 7 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1001000 New Sale                      12513
 8 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1271000 New Sale                      12838
 9 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1310000 New Sale                      12970
10 RIVERFRONT RESIDE…                1339000 New Sale                      13000
# ℹ 77 more rows
# ℹ 1 more variable: `Property Type` <chr>


Notes: eval (display the code but does not run it), echo (runs the code but does not display it), %>% (used to combine multiple functions together)

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Loading tidyverse onto r environment by using the code chunk below

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)



Code chunk below uses read_csv() of readr to import Exam_data.csv into r environment as a tibble data.frame.

exam_data <- read_csv("chap01/data/Exam_data.csv")




First, let us compare the differences between R Graphics, the core graphical functions of Base R and ggplot in plotting a simple histogram.

hist(exam_data$MATHS)







ggplot(data=exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=10, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="black", 
                 fill="grey") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               tidyverse)

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               tidyverse)

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text: Beyond ggplot2: ggrepel

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text: Beyond ggplot2 Themes

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Working with hrbthems

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_ipsum()









ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_ipsum(axis_title_size = 18,
              base_size = 15,
              grid = "Y")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text: Beyond Single Graph

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
References

Prof Kam Tin Seong (2025) https://r4va.netlify.app/chap02. Online version

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Without ggrepel

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  geom_label(aes(label = ID), 
             hjust = .5, 
             vjust = -.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
With ggrepel

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ID), 
                   fontface = "bold") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Gray Theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  theme_gray() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Economist Theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_economist()

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Normal Plots

p1 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") + 
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")


p2 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of English scores")


p3 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x= MATHS, 
                 y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Creating Composite Graphics with patchwork
Side-by-side

p1 + p2








“/” operator to stack two ggplot2 graphs, “|” operator to place the plots beside each other, “()” operator the define the sequence of the plotting.

(p1 / p2) | p3








Auto-tagging

((p1 / p2) | p3) + 
  plot_annotation(tag_levels = 'I')

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Creating Composite Graphics with Inset

p3 + inset_element(p2, 
                   left = 0.02, 
                   bottom = 0.7, 
                   right = 0.5, 
                   top = 1)

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
section: Creating a composite figure using patchwork and ggtheme
text:
Creating a composite figure using patchwork and ggtheme

patchwork <- (p1 / p2) | p3
patchwork & theme_economist()

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
First, let us compare the differences between R Graphics, the core graphical functions of Base R and ggplot in plotting a simple histogram.

hist(exam_data$MATHS)







ggplot(data=exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=10, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="black", 
                 fill="grey") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Blank Canvas

ggplot(data=exam_data)








Including the x-axis and the axis’s label

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS))

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Plotting a bar chart

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Plotting a dot plot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.5)








Improve the visual by removing the y-axis and changing the binwidth

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth=2.5,         
               dotsize = 0.5) +      
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,           
                     breaks = NULL)

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Plotting a histogram

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram() 








Modifying the histogram

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20,            
                 color="black",      
                 fill="light blue")  








Providing additional info by sub grouping the visual

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           fill = GENDER)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 color="grey30")

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
section: Plotting a kernel density estimate plot
text:
Plotting a kernel density estimate plot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_density() 








Providing additional info by sub grouping the visual

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS, 
           colour = GENDER)) +
  geom_density()

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Plotting a box plot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS,       
           x= GENDER)) +    
  geom_boxplot()








Improving the visual by converting the boxplot into a notched plot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch=TRUE)

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Plotting a violin plot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_violin()

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Plotting a scatter plot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point()

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Combining different types of plots

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +                    
  geom_point(position="jitter", 
             size = 0.5)

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Basic box plot
Without means

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot()








With means (Method 1)

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun = "mean",         
               colour ="red",        
               size=4)       








With means (Method 2)

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat="summary",        
             fun="mean",           
             colour="red",          
             size=4)

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
section: Adding a best fit curve on a scatterplot
text:
Adding a best fit curve on a scatterplot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(linewidth=0.5)








Utilizing of another smoothing method

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              linewidth=0.5)

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Facet_wrap()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_wrap(~ CLASS)

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Facet_grid()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_grid(~ CLASS)

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Default bar chart

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar()








With coord_flip()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip()

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Default scatterplot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, size=0.5)








With the y-axis and x-axis being fixed from 0-100

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Gray Theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_gray()

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Classic Theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_classic()

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Minimal Theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal()

With the y-axis and x-axis being fixed from 0-100

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Gray Theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_gray()

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Classic Theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_classic()

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Minimal Theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal()

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               tidyverse)

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Without ggrepel

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  geom_label(aes(label = ID), 
             hjust = .5, 
             vjust = -.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
With ggrepel

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ID), 
                   fontface = "bold") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Gray Theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  theme_gray() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Economist Theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_economist()

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Normal Plots

p1 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") + 
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")


p2 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of English scores")


p3 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x= MATHS, 
                 y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Creating Composite Graphics with patchwork
Side-by-side

p1 + p2








“/” operator to stack two ggplot2 graphs, “|” operator to place the plots beside each other, “()” operator the define the sequence of the plotting.

(p1 / p2) | p3








Auto-tagging

((p1 / p2) | p3) + 
  plot_annotation(tag_levels = 'I')

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Creating Composite Graphics with Inset

p3 + inset_element(p2, 
                   left = 0.02, 
                   bottom = 0.7, 
                   right = 0.5, 
                   top = 1)

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
section: Creating a composite figure using patchwork and ggtheme
text:
Creating a composite figure using patchwork and ggtheme

patchwork <- (p1 / p2) | p3
patchwork & theme_economist()
